Fort Sill
Oklahoma Territory 
Mch 12/97
My dear Uncle & Aunt
I arrived here 
this forenoon.  I saw 
General Merritt in 
Chicago and he gave me 
two nice letters here.  
I called upon The 
Colonel here and he 
introduced me around 
Capt Scott whom I 
have a letter to is 
not here now but 
will be Tomorrow - he 
has charge of the Appache tribe. 
I never was treated

any better in my life 
than I was here 
a Capt Hoyle here has 
taken quite a fancy 
to me he has insisted 
on me living with 
him in his quarters 
he has a whole house 
to him self he is 
alone as his wife is 
away on a visit and 
he wants me to take 
the best room in the 
house and eat with 
him he has a Chinese 
cook says I can 
have a soldier to 
waite upon me 
and have a fine 
horse to ride and 
will not listen to

(3)
me paying for any-
thing so I will get 
a photo? of him and 
make him a picture 
of himself on a horse
when I return.  
The first thing after 
Dinner I hunted up 
Chief Geronimo he 
lives two miles from 
the Fort in a house 
I found his house, 
wrapped? on the door 
but no one was in 
but an Indian near
by who spoke pretty 
good English told me 
Geronimo was out 
getting some ponies 
I saw him way 
off in the distance 
and waited for him 
pretty soon he came

on horse back (he can 
ride fine) when he came 
up to me I said 
How do you do 
Chief Geronimo he looked
at me in a surprised 
way and held out his 
hand and we shook 
hands I gave him 
a box of cigarettes
He smoked and offered 
me one motioned 
for me to sit down 
and we smoked the 
cigarette of Peace
He doesn't speak 
English but an 
Indian was there
who did and 
I had a two hours 
conversation with 
Geronimo he is a

(5)   fine specimen of an 
Indian and a nice 
old fellow 62 years old, 
hair as black as jet 
He likes to joke he 
said he had got through 
being an Indian was 
a white man now 
he invited me to his 
house we went in 
and sat down, he 
the other Indian and 
two squaws and two 
pappooses and my
self.  He says he will 
sit for me any time 
and that I can use 
his house for a 
studio which am 
going to do so will 
commence his picture 
Tomorrow and he 
is going to dress up
3-12-97

for me with a 
war bonnet on and 
an Indian blanket 
on also. I am going 
to paint Geronimos 
grand son. They say 
here that Geronimo 
was the medicine 
man to the Appache 
tribe and that an 
Indian by the name 
of Natchie was the 
war chief of the 
Appaches and he 
is also here. There 
are 3000 Indians here 
so you see I have 
plenty of subjects. 
The Commanchies 
and the Kiowans 
are the most interesting 
to paint as a good

(7)  many of them have 
their native clothes 
to wear and do 
wear them. There are 
a lot of Teapes here 
some of the Indians 
prefer living in them. 
Capt Scott they 
tell me has a fine 
collection of Indian things. 
The Capt that I am 
staying with has been 
in service twenty years 
among the Indians and 
has had a good 
many battles with 
them. Am glad I 
brought my wheel 
as the roads are fine 
here. quite a number 
of wheels are here. 
Geronimo goes around 
with Soldiers clothes
3-12-97

on. 
Well I must close 
will let you know 
later on how I 
get along. 
A person is safer 
here among these 
Indians than he is 
in Chicago I believe. 
I believe he would 
get killed in Chicago 
sooner than here. 
Wishing you a pleasant 
journey. Am your affect. 
nephew 
Elbridge.

Fort Sill
Oklahoma Ty
Mch 14/97
My Dear Uncle
I will start 
Geronimos portrait 
tomorrow Capt Scott 
who I had a letter to 
and who has charge 
of the Indians here has 
been away and did not 
return until yesterday 
afternoon. I intended 
to start Geronimos portrait 
the next day after I 
saw him but the Capt 
I am rooming with told 
me I would have to 
get permission from 
Capt Scott first. 
Capt Scott invited me

to Dinner last eve 
and Uncle Ed I want 
you to meet that 
man he has spent 
20 years of his life among 
the Indians and he has 
a fine collection of 
Indian things that different 
chiefs have given him 
and what he has got in 
Indian battle fields. he speaks 
several Indian languages 
and also speaks the 
Indian sign language. 
He gave a lecture at 
the Congress held at 
the Art Institute during 
the Worlds Fair on 
the sign language Gen 
Miles got him to deliver 
it He has got a 
parchement of the

(3)
Kiowan Indians 
it is made by one 
of the tribe giving their 
whole History in different 
characters he has the 
original the Smithsonian 
Institute at Washington 
is to publish it soon is 
to to be illustrated and 
will be published soon 
You just ought to see 
the work that man 
does here for the 
Indians this afternoon 
he took me in a 
buggy all around 
the Reservation and 
showed me houses 
barns hay stacks? farming 
etc the Apache Indians 
are doing old Geronimo 
does farm work 
and all the noted

chiefs do farm work 
here. He goes to Washington 
now and then he has 
got to go again about 
June and I want you 
to meet him. When you 
return you ought to 
come here you would 
be surprised to see the 
collection of Indian 
things some of these 
Indian fighters have 
I met Capt Baldwin 
who is a celebrated 
Indian fighter his 
name is spoken of 
very highly in Gen 
Miles book The Capt 
told me lots about 
the Indians. Capt Scott is very 
anxious to meet you

(5)
and wants you to 
come out here. He 
wants me to go 
with him on an 
8 days trip on horse 
back with a pack 
mule and an Indian 
along for a cook. 
We called at Geronimos 
house this afternoon 
but he was out so 
the Capt left word 
for Geronimo to come 
to his house and I am 
to be there also and 
arrangements are to be 
made to paint his 
portrait. The Indians 
will do anything 
for Capt Scott. 
Capt Scott has 15 hounds 
and takes them and 
hunts wolfs

It is very interesting to 
go to the trading stand? store? 
and watch the different 
tribes of Indians come 
in to trade An old Indian 
Kiawan squaw wanted 
me to go in her Tipi but 
I was afraid to and 
didn't go in I told Capt 
Scott about it and 
he said I was safer in 
there than in Church. 
The first night I was 
here I locked my door 
as I was so far West 
and 3000 Indians 
all around me thought 
it wise to do so. Do 
you known the whole 
Fort knows of it and 
joke me about it. 
They say that is

(7) the first door that 
has been locked here 
in 20 years.  I dont lock
my door any more.  
Capt Scott took me 
to the house where 
Custer and Sheridan 
camped in 1868 they dug 
holes in the ground and 
placed their tents over 
the holes the holes 
protected the soldiers 
from the winds, the 
holes are ? here seem? seen?
none very plain.
I made a sketch 
today of a fence and?
gate made by the 
Appache Indians
which is interesting 
and unique.  I get 
up by bugle call

eat by bugle call 
and go to bed by 
bugle call.  They are 
very strict here one day 
I was talking with 
some soldiers and 
afterwards an officer 
came to me and in a 
nice way told me 
that as I was stopping 
with a Captain I must 
not associate with 
the soldiers. I never was 
treated any nicer 
in my life than I 
am here they cant 
do enough for me 
they do so much for 
me that they just 
bother? me & they wont 
let me pay for what 
I eat but I shall

(9) but I shall insist 
on paying as expect 
to be here a few weeks.
I have just returned 
from Capt Scotts 
Geronimo was there 
waiting for me and 
as luck would have 
it twelve Comanchie 
chiefs were waiting outside 
the house to see the 
Capt as I went in 
The Captain invited 
them all in. Geronimo 
was sitting in another 
room, he came in 
and sat down beside me 
and shook hands 
then there were 13
chiefs and Capt 
Scott and my self. 
The Indians all 
sat around in a ring

The Capt told me to 
talk to Geronimo and 
make arrangements with 
him which I did through 
an Indian interpreter. 
Geronimo is to fix him 
self up in his native 
dress. You know the 
Appache tribe wore 
a cloth around their 
head and scarcely 
any clothes did'nt 
have any clothes on 
the upper body. 
Geronimo remained a 
while to listen to 
what the Comanchies 
had to say and then 
went home. It was 
the most interesting 
eve I ever spent in 
my life. There was

(11)
12 Comanchie Chiefs among 
them the principal chief 
now living Looking Glass 
and most of them in 
native dress They came 
to see Capt Scott on 
business. Whenever the 
Capt goes away they 
want to know where 
he has gone and what 
he went for, he went 
to Texas to the cattle 
convention Chief Looking 
Glass had the most to 
say and Capt doesn't 
understand the Comanchie 
language so had an 
Indian interpreter present 
After the Capt had 
explayned why he 
had gone to Texas 
then Looking Glass

(13)
The Capt. When they 
started for home I 
went out with them 
and the interpreter who 
is a fine specimen of 
a Comanchie asked me 
about Geronimos picture 
and said if I would 
paint him he would 
dress in Comanchie 
costume says he has 
a fine suit and that 
he will sit as long as 
I want him to, so 
you see I am getting 
along fine. I am to 
start Geronimos picture 
in the morning and will 
work in his house I 
will paint two of him 
a front view and 
a profile he has a 
fine head. Well

Uncle Ed if this letter 
didnt dwell principally 
upon Indians don't 
think you would have 
the patience to read it 
all. 
Give my love to 
Aunt Emma 
Your affect. 
nephew 
Elbridge

Sunday Fort Sill O. T. 
Mch 21/97
My dear Uncle & Aunt
I finished with 
Chief Geronimo today 
I have painted two 
fine likenesses of him 
one a front view 
and the other a profile 
and I have painted him 
with his correct costume 
on. Geronimo is rather 
a mean man his acqua-
intance does'nt  wear 
very well at times he 
has a very ugly look 
he is so terribly greedy 
for money. I was going 
to paint a third picture 
of him in war paint

he promised to paint his 
face up. but he backed 
out, you ought to see 
how pleased he was 
with his picture he would 
have the different Indians 
come in and criticise they 
all like the picture 
when I got through 
Geronimo patted me on 
the back and says good 
man, good man. The 
Officers here and other 
people have tried time 
and again to get Geron-
imo to tell some of 
his past life and he 
would'nt say a word. 
Today there was an Indian 
present Appache who 
spoke fine English 
and I had quite a

(3) conversation with the 
Chief. I tried from the 
first to get him to 
like me and succeeded 
I gave his squaw presents 
and brought him a 
chair to sit in and 
every time I came to 
paint him gave his 
two? children little 
things which pleased 
the old man as he 
thinks the world of his 
family. I told him 
today he ought to 
write his history 
and if he would I 
would see that it 
was published and 
that he could make 
a lot of money by 
it (which struck a tender 
cord with him as he 
is very fond of making

money)  He promised me he 
would, he said he would 
tell me a long story 
of his life and wanted 
me to write it down 
I wanted him to tell 
me right then but he 
said he was tired 
from sitting but for 
me to come any time 
and he would, now 
an Indian you know 
as a rule will stick 
to a promise. I have 
found that out so 
I will have an interpreter 
with me when I go 
again. I told some 
of the officers here and 
they said to go there by 
all means as it 
would be valuable to

(5) have Geronimo has made 
me a fine bow and 
fine arrows. I saw 
him make them, he 
would work on them 
when he was resting from 
sitting. He has signed 
his name to both 
of the pictures I painted 
of him, had a hard time 
to get him to do it. 
The Officers here say 
Geronimo was'nt the 
head chief of the Appache 
was only a medicine 
man but the Indians 
here say he was the 
great Chief I know 
an Indian here who 
remembers him when 
he was running wild 
and was with him 
and he says Geronimo 
was the head man

The Officer claims 
Natchie was the Chief 
that Natchie was the 
hereditary Chief Natchie 
is here and I have 
seen him I never saw 
a finer specimen of 
an Indian than he is 
a noble looking fellow 
a refined face while 
Geronimo has an ugly 
beast looking face. 
Several Artists have 
tried to paint 
Natchie.  Farnes came 
here to paint him and 
Natchie turned his 
back to him and 
walked off, but 
I am going to paint 
him this week as 
he has promised to

(7) sit for me. I am 
to go to his house three 
miles from here any 
time I am ready. 
Today I started another 
picture of the prettiest 
Indian girl I ever saw 
she is the bell here she 
is a Kiawa Indian 
and her Father & Grand 
Father were noted chiefs 
her name is Gi-aum-e 
Hom-o-mea-tah grand 
daughter to Chief To-harsen 
which means Little mountain 
she has an elegant 
Indian costume made 
by her mother who is 
a celebrated bead worker 
here (her mother is making 
me a fine pair of moccasins 
she took my measure) 
her costume has over 
100 Elk teeth on it

and fine bead work on 
it.  She is a perfect 
little lady has such 
nice manners etc she 
had another Indian 
girl with her as she 
didn’t think it proper 
for her to be with me 
in a room alone.  
She just happened to 
be here she lives 12 
miles from here in the 
mountains and her 
parents will stay over 
until I finish the 
picture. Soon as am 
through with her and 
Natchie am going to 
paint a Comanche 
Chief called Looking 
Glass.  Yesterday 
was beef day here

here for the Comanche & 
Kiowas which takes 
place once a month 
two and a half miles 
from here a party of 
us went to see it 
which was a sight 
The Cattle are given to 
the Indians alive and 
the Indians ride on horse 
back and shoot the 
cattle down there is 
one cow to three families 
The minute the cow 
drops the squaws run 
up with knifes and 
carve it.  The Indians 
come from all over 
the reservation two 
and three days before 
beef day and camp 
out they bring tents 
and the whole family 
papooses dogs etc

They will take the 
kidneys liver and 
the tripe and eat it 
raw and the dogs at 
least six or seven of 
them will chew away 
at the animal while 
the squaws are carving.  
I have a nice pony to 
ride here.  A man 
who has charge of the 
Indian store here told 
me he knew where there 
was a genuine old 
Buffalo skin Tipi 
he says the skins are 
buried and covered 
over with leaves and 
packed in leaves to preserve 
it that it is complete 
seems to me that would 
be a fine thing have 
for the Museum to

(11) have it all set up.  
The Indians I paint 
here I have them dressed 
up correct as so many 
of the Officers especially 
Capt. Scott has a 
big collection of things 
that I can use any 
time I wont paint the 
Indians with half 
American clothes on 
as it spoils the whole 
thing.  I couldn’t possibly 
of come to a better place 
for the Apache Comanche 
and Kiowa Indians than 
here and every body is 
so nice to me.  I have 
a fine Studio to work 
in if wish to.  
I wrote to a friend of 
mine in Cincinnati 
who knows Rothenburg 
to write to you giving

directions etc about the 
place he has written me 
that he has.  I also send 
you a diagram.  This is 
the third letter have 
written you.  When I get 
through here expect to 
go 38 miles from here 
by stage to where 
there are a lot more 
Indians of a different 
tribe Maj. Baldwin 
has charge of the place 
and wants me to come.
Affectionately, 
Your nephew,
Elbridge
P.S. I may not go to Somerville 
don’t care much about 
painting darkeys for a 
while, not while can get 
such fine models as these 
Indians are.

Fort Sill
Oklahoma	
Mch 25/97 
Territory
My dear Uncle & Aunt,
Have made up my 
mind not to go to 
Somerville Texas, don’t 
want to waste any time 
going there and painting 
inappropriate reference, I never was 
so well satisfied with 
painting anything as am 
with these Indians 
I wish you both could 
see now a picture 
have finished of a Kiowa 
Indian girl dressed up 
in her native costume 
I never painted a more 
beautiful picture in 
my life her costume is

is marvelous in color 
I have two Indians sitting 
for me every day one 
in the forenoon and one 
in the afternoon, in the 
afternoon am painting 
another Kiowa girl full 
length with a beautiful 
costume that the doctor 
here loaned me a genuine 
Kiowa costume.  I had 
some trouble with the 
two Indian girls.  After 
I had started the pictures 
they didn’t want to sit 
any more.  One morning 
they didn’t come, so 
I went after them and 
they came at noon 
and said we sit no 
more, tired of sitting.  Well 
I wasn’t in a good

humor and just give 
them thunder and they 
commenced to sit.  I told 
Capt. Scott and he told 
their Father and now 
they sit fine, but how 
they do hate it.  They sing 
Indian songs most all 
the time.  When the Indian 
saw my finished pictures 
they didn’t know what 
to make of it one of them 
said I made strong 
medicine that enabled 
me to do it, so now 
I am a big man in 
their estimation.  
I just got Chief Natche 
the rightful Chief of the 
Apaches by inheritance 
to sit for me this forenoon 
have been at him ever 
since have been here

Artists have tried to 
have him sit for them and he 
wouldn’t he was offered 
$100.00 if he would sit 
and turned his back on them 
and walked off I give 
him a dollar a sitting 
for four hours, he will 
sit for me every other 
morning and the Indian 
girl the other mornings 
Am making arrangements 
now for Looking Glass 
Chief of the Comanches 
to sit for me in full 
war costume Capt. Scott 
who has been with the 
Indians 20 years and 
who is a fine judge 
of their costumes sees 
that I have the right 
costumes. Will try and

remain here until the 
hot weather sets in which 
wont be for two months 
yet, then I want to 
go North where 
Chief Joseph is.  He 
is some where in Montana. 
I never dreamed what the 
Indians were until I 
came here.  It is impossible 
to paint anything more 
picturesque than these Indian are in their 
costumes.  Natche is 
a fine looking man 
such fine features and 
such a nice expression 
to his face and such 
nice manners but they 
tell me he was a 
perfect devil when he 
was with Geronimo 
Before I leave here expect 
to have at least 25 pictures

I work every day Sunday 
and all, when I return 
to Chicago will have a 
private exhibition of 
nothing but Indian 
pictures and every one 
of them correct as far 
as costume goes I won’t 
have a Kiowa moccasin 
on an Apache Indian.  
I want to ask you a 
question; do you know 
the difference between 
a Kiowa moccasin and 
an Apache one? I do.  
After I get through work 
take long rides on my 
wheel the roads are 
good here and perfectly 
dry, the weather is 
beautiful peach trees 
in blossom grass green etc.

If I want to go to 
Montana from here 
do you suppose you 
could get me a fare?  
Won’t go for two months 
yet.  After I get through 
here there is no use of 
me returning to Chicago 
not until Fall any way.  
I just feel as though 
I had lost a pile of 
time in not painting 
these Indians before 
and don’t want to loose 
time by getting away 
from them Since have 
finished with Geronimo 
am working in a room 
with a North light 
that one of the Lieutenants 
let me have and have 
the Indians come to me 
to pose for me.

Capt Scott is awfully 
enthusiastic over my 
pictures, and he wished 
he could have them that 
if he had money he 
would buy every one of them. 
The first spare time I 
have am going over 
to see Geronimo and have 
him tell me his life, 
several people have been 
at him to tell 
them his life but he 
wouldn't say a word. 
He seems to like me, 
he has a cat and he keeps 
the cats whiskers clipped close 
all the time. Well 
I must close Expect you 
are having a nice time, hope 
you both are enjoying good 
health. Your affect nephew 
E. A. Burbridge

Fort Sill 
Oklahoma Territory
Mch 28/97
My dear Uncle,
You are responsible 
for getting me to come 
here so now I am 
going to bother you now 
and then with letters.  
Uncle Ed I never was 
so well satisfied and 
never so taken with 
a subject as I am 
with these Indians.  
I have made arrangements 
to stay right here all 
Summer am not going 
back to Chicago until 
next fall.  I couldn’t 
have things fixed finer

for work than I have 
here, pretty soon I am 
going to a Comanche 
camp of Indians some 
20 miles from here 
there are some fine old 
Chiefs I want to paint 
there I have a team now 
loaned to me and will 
take a blanked and 
my painting materials with 
me and paint and live 
with them.  Capt. Scott 
is going to let me take 
some Comanche costumes 
with me to put on the 
Indians in case they 
haven’t any.  I will bet you 
now that when I come 
back to Chicago you 
won’t say I have this 
or that wrong on the

(3) Indian.  I am not 
going to Somerville at 
all I have now finished 
four pictures and tomorrow 
will have a 13 X 20 inches 
in size finished of a 
Kiowa girl in a most 
beautiful Kiowa costume 
showing full figure.  
Capt. Scott was in to 
see it today and wish 
you could hear him talk 
about it Capt. Scott is 
going to give me lessons 
in the sign language 
last eve a Lieutenant 
and my self went 
to the Kiowa camp a 
mile from here and went 
in the Tipi there were 11 
Indians inside they 
made a place for us and 
we had a fine 
time.  it was pitch 
dark outside and the

little fire in the center 
of the Tipi and Indians 
sitting all around it 
was fine only one of 
them spoke English. 
Yesterday afternoon the 
model wasn't feeling 
well so I got on my 
wheel and went to 
see my friend Geronimo 
he was glad to see me 
wondered why I didn't 
come to see him oftener. 
I went then to got him 
to commence to tell me 
his life so I got an 
Indian interpreter and 
had a lot of paper 
with me, and Geronimo 
commenced He commenced 
from the time he first 
remembered things when

a small boy which 
was the naked 
dances they had and 
he also said he noticed 
that there were a great 
many Indians he said he 
danced about in 50 of 
these dances and then 
went on a war path 
when still a young man.  
I wrote down 11 pages 
and he got tired, he 
goes into detail which 
told him to do how 
he killed people etc up 
to the time he had told 
me it was principally 
raids in Mexico now 
and then they would meet 
the Mexican troops and 
have a fight and quite 
often would creep up to 
a small village and

kill everybody.  The interpreter 
is an Appache and his 
Father was a Chief before 
Geronimo his Father was 
killed and Geronimo took 
his place this interpreter 
was with Geronimo when 
Geronimo gave him self 
up, Geronimo told 
when once the Mexicans 
came to their camp in a 
friendly way and gave 
the Indians whiskey and 
when they were good & 
drunk shot into them 
and killed 46 Indians 
Geronimo gets as excited 
when he is talking and 
tires himself all out 
What an active old 
fellow he was as he 
was on the go all the time.

time. The only way I 
could get him to tell 
his life was that if 
it was interesting he could 
make some money out 
of it that I was sure 
some publishers would 
take it and that I 
would loan his picture 
I have painted of him 
for the frontispiece. 
A good many people have 
been at him to tell his 
life and he wouldn't open 
his mouth, but he has 
promised me to tell his 
whole life as full as 
he can he says anytime 
I come up he will go 
on where he left off and 
while I am away will 
think of his life I would 
go up there every eve

but he doesn't want me 
to come there some? times
that I do not feel like 
working will go up he 
says it will take a long 
time to write it, he says 
at the time he was telling 
of his life. They only had 
bows, arrows & spears. 
He is awfully greedy for 
money, he is not liked 
here at all on that 
account, every time I see 
him he has something 
to sell me. I have 
painted a good portrait 
of Chief Nachie an 
Appache he has a fine 
face such an intelligent 
face and a nice fellow 
am going to start 
another one of him

(9) tomorrow.  Capt. Scott 
thinks he is the principal 
Indian here, have 
painted him in his 
native costume with 
a red cloth tied around 
his head  These two 
Indian girls that have 
been painting bring one 
of their medicine rattlers 
with them and they 
sing and rattle it all 
day.  An old Indian 
squaw is making me 
a fine pair of moccasins 
she took my measure 
she is said to be the 
finest bead worker here 
Capt. Scott has a 
fine Kiowa dress which 
am going to paint it has 
400 elk teeth on it.  
A number of Indians

held a consul here 
yesterday to see who 
would go to Washington 
Capt. Scott is going to 
Washington with a 
delegation of Indians in a month 
or two.  Wish you were 
to be in Chicago when 
he goes as want you to 
meet him The Indians 
that are going with him 
are all Chiefs.  
Well I must close 
and go to bed.  
With love to you 
both.
Am your affect 
nephew,
Elbridge

Fort Sill
Oklahoma 
Territory	
April 4/97
My dear Uncle & Aunt,
The weather here 
is simply beautiful.  
I was going over to see 
Geronimo today and 
broke the seat on my 
wheel.  Wish you could see 
some Indians that are 
sitting for me now I 
never saw any thing so 
beautiful in color, the 
pictures am painting now 
are mostly full length 
in full Indian costume 
am painting them 13 X 20 
in size I have 4 
Indians engaged ahead

to paint one of them 
is going to fix up in 
war paint and wear 
a war bonnet he came 
to see me he is a tall 
6 ft fellow and has a 
war bonnet that reached 
to the floor covered with 
feathers am anxious to 
get at him.  You would 
of laughed if you could of 
peeked into my Studio 
yesterday you would of 
seen seven or eight 
Indians sitting on the 
floor back of me 
watching me paint.

Now I will tell you my 
plans.  I stopped at 
Ft. Custer, 11 miles from 
here to see Jim Campbell
Sheridan’s favorite Scout.  
Had a nice visit with 
him but there are no 
Indians there and he 
told me to come here.  At 
the present time there is 
not a single Indian here, 
they have a 10 days leave 
and gone to Sheridan 
for the 4th but will 
return the 6th of July.  The 
people here tell me the 
Crows nearly all of them 
paint and wear blankets 
and a great number 
of them have their native

dress because they have 
dances so much and 
Mr. Barstow who has 
charge here is a fine 
man and a crank on 
Indians has a lot 
of war bonnets, costumes, 
etc., told me I could 
get all the Indians wanted 
to paint and he would 
have them fix up for me.  
Tomorrow I am going 
40 miles from here to a 
place on the Little Horn 
River.  There are a thousand 
Indians there for the 4th 
and every one of them is 
to be dressed up in war 
costumes and they are 
going to give War Dances.  
A man there, a Mr. 
Graves whom I met 
in Billings, has charge

(5) there - has invited me 
to come and I will 
stay there and paint 
until the Indians come 
back here then I will 
return, when am through 
here am going to the 
Cheyenne Indians 60 
miles from here then 
I will return to Billings 
and paint two Indian 
Chiefs that Mr. Weare 
wanted me to get. One 
is Plenty Coupse and 
Pretty Eagle.  One is 20 
miles and the other 30 
miles from Billings.  
Then I will go for 
Chief Joseph, then am 
coming back to Billings 
and take the Burlington 
Road which runs through 
here and go for 350 miles

to the Pine Ridge Agency 
where the Sioux are.  
I am not at all 
satisfied what have 
done with the Sioux.  
Ft. Yates isn’t a good 
place, they are too 
civilized for me but 
they tell me at Pine 
Ridge Agency they are not, 
that they paint and 
dress in native clothes.  
“Rain-in-the-face” told me 
himself so and said 
his whole costume was 
there.  He gave it to some 
Indians there.  When I 
get through at Pine Ridge 
will catch a ride 
with an Indian or some-
one and go 200 miles 
by wagon to Rock Creek 
and will get the Indians

(7) that I couldn’t get 
this time, will get 
a profile of “Rain-in-the-
face” wanted him to sit 
again but he said it 
made him sick then 
another thing I have a 
scheme when I can 
get “Rain-in-the-face” to 
tell me the part he took 
in the Custer fight you 
see if I don’t.  From Rock 
Creek will go right on 
to Ft. Yates and get 
two Indians celebrated 
ones that are away now 
then will go to Cannon 
Ball which is all on 
my way and all by 
wagon and there 
are 3 or 4 celebrated 
Indians I want.  I 
stopped at Cannon Ball

on my way here and 
there wasn’t a single 
Indian there had all 
gone for the 4th from 
there will go to Bismarck 
and on to Chicago 
it will be better to go 
as I have told you than 
to go by rail to St. Paul 
and from there to Pine 
Ridge.  The distance is 
further.  Where I am stopping 
here the Custer battlefield 
is three miles away you 
can see Custer Monument 
from here. Went there 
this afternoon, as my 
wheel was all over the 
place, the government 
has a man stationed 
there all the time to tell 
strangers about the 
fight.  At Ft. Yates

(9) Tom Custer, Gen. Custer’s 
brother arrested “Rain-in-
the-face”.  They show you 
the very spot where it 
happened and the man 
who told me heard 
“Rain-in-the-face” say 
that he would kill 
Tom Custer and cut his heart 
out and eat it and 
he kept his word.  The 
man who has charge of 
the house where I am 
stopping was in the 
Custer battle field right 
after it was over and 
he said he got some of 
the finest costumes he 
every saw he stripped 
them off from dead 
Indians and gave 
them to the museum 
in Washington.

Mr. Barstow here 
has got 100 pictures 
that an Indian Artist 
drew illustrating what 
he saw in going to 
Washington will see 
then when I return in 
a week or so.  
I want you to do 
something for me 
wish you would 
send a check to 
Tot for $50.00 her 
address is Care of 
William Thorne 24 
West 59th Street New York.  
and I wish you would 
send me a check for 
$100.00 and let it go on 
the pictures this trip 
is costing me more 
than at Ft. Sill as

(11) I have to travel 
around so much but 
I am located right here 
for some time.  The 
Crows and Cheyenne 
do the most beautiful 
bead work ever saw 
Do you think you could 
get me a pass from 
Billings to Deadwood 
on the Burlington Road? 
The Pine Ridge is about 
40 miles by stage from 
Deadwood the fare 
is about $25.00 from 
Billings.
Your affectionate 
nephew,
Elbridge
P.S. Give my love to all.  
You can address me 
to Crow Agency, 
Mont.

P.S. When you write you 
can address to 
Crow Agency, 
Mont.
Ditch Camp, Mont
July 4/97
My dear Uncle
I wish you could 
of been with me today and 
seen the War Dance it was 
the most gorgeous thing ever 
saw there are 1,000 Indians 
here and every one is painted 
up and have native costumes 
on the men are naked except 
breech cloth on and their bodies 
and faces are painted and 
tattooed all colors and 
they have on all sorts of 
head gear, war bonnets, etc.

The Crows are the best 
Indians seen yet the most 
artistic and nearly all 
of them has their native 
costumes war bonnets etc 
as they dance a good deal 
I asked several Indians 
if they would fix up like 
they were now for me 
and they said they would.  
Am painting an Indian 
in his Tipi.  I will get 
all the subjects can 
paint for 20 years here 
or at Crow Agency as 
most of the Indians here 
belong there. Between here

and Crow Agency a 
Mr. Campbell lives.  Remington, 
Walter Shirlaw & De Forest 
Brush have stopped with 
him Brush for 2 years 
and he has invited me 
to stop with him.  Pretty 
Eagle, the principal Chief 
of the Crows lives 3 miles 
from him and he is to 
sit in Mr. Campbell’s house 
for me all fixed up.  
Mr. P. B. Weare of Chicago 
wanted me to be sure and 
get a portrait of him.  
The government is putting in 
a big irrigating ditch here.  
I eat and sleep with 
the ditch men no other 
place can’t stand their 
food but I will be going 
away from here to Crow 
Agency soon.  Do you know

how an Indian washes 
his face saw one do it to 
day they fill their mouth 
full of water and squirt 
it on their hands and 
then wash, by having the water 
in their mouth they warm it a 
little, then I saw some Indians 
taking a Turkish bath they 
take some sticks and make 
an oval house about 10 ft 
long and 8 wide and 4 high 
and cover it all over almost air 
tight with robes etc then they heat 
a lot of stones hot and put them 
in center of the place and they get 
in there naked and pour water 
on the stones which makes steam.  
An Indian told me today that 
he had a lot of old swords that he 
found in the Custer battle field he 
wants to sell them.
Your affect nephew,
Elbridge

St. Xaviar, Mont	
July 7/97
My dear Uncle
I got here today 
this is a sub Indian 
Agency and also the 
Catholic mission for 
Indians is here.  It is 
on the way to Crow Agency 
and 25 miles from there.  
The Indians that went 
to the War Dance at Ditch Camp 
17 miles from here 
have gone back to their 
homes.  The dance lasted 
4 days and was the 
finest thing I ever saw

I couldn’t do much work 
while it was going on 
but nearly finished one 
picture of an Indian there 
in fine costume he has 
gone to the Crow Agency 
and will finish it there. 
At the dance the Indians 
gave ponies away also blankets, 
wagons, carriages, etc.  
If you have never seen a 
War dance you will never 
regret it if you come here 
some time and see one.  
Who do you think sat 
for me at the Ditch Camp 
he happened to be there and 
I have got a fine picture 
of him, it was Curley.  He 
you know was Custer’s 
Scout when Custer was 
killed and was the only

(3) man with Custer who 
got away alive he is a big 
fellow fine fellow he 
sat all day for me painted 
a small one of him at 
Noon invited him, his squaw 
and little papoose to Dinner 
with me so he hitched up 
his team and we drove 2 miles 
to where the hotel was 
simply a log house.  
Curley at the very first of 
the fight saw that it 
was sure death for the 
soldiers from the thousands 
of Sioux, commenced right 
off to fix his hair like 
a Sioux and then went to 
a dead Sioux Indian and 
took the Sioux things and 
put them on himself 
and then joined the Sioux

and acted as though he 
was a Sioux and the first 
chance he got lit out 
and notified the government 
troops what had happened 
he speaks a little English 
and he told me he was 
going to Crow Agency and 
would take me on the 
battlefield himself and 
explain things.  While I was 
looking at the War Dance 
there was several Indians that 
I admired their get 
up more than others and 
do you know those very same 
Indians are right here.  
The man Mr. Campbell 
who am stopping with 
is one of the finest men ever 
met he has taken me in 
his home lets me have the 
whole house to work in

(5) his wife is away on a 
visit so he does the 
house work cooking and 
all and is a good cook 
You ought to of been present 
this afternoon in Mr. 
Campbell’s store a lot 
of Indians came in and 
Chief Pretty Eagle with 
them he did the talking 
they came in to tell their 
troubles how badly they 
are treated by the Agency 
here Mr. Campbell translated 
to me and it would make 
tears come to your eyes 
to hear them Pretty Eagle 
turned to me and says 
what would you do.  I said 
I wouldn’t stand it he says 
what can we do if we make 
any trouble there would be 
enough soldiers sent here

to kill us all but he 
says as for me I would 
rather be shot than starved 
but we have children and 
what would become of them 
etc, some time when I see 
you I will tell you some things 
about the treatment these 
Indians receive which will 
surprise you and I have got it 
right straight from Mr. 
Campbell and the Indians.  
The Indians are so honest 
and patient that I feel 
so sorry for them and as 
a class I like them better 
than the white people.  Mr. 
Campbell told me if there 
were no white people around 
here he wouldn’t lock the 
door to his store and could 
stay away a month and

(7) the Indians 
wouldn’t touch a thing.  
I have heard so much 
about Mr. Campbell 
since have been in this 
country what an up-
right square honest man 
he is and one doesn’t have 
to be with him a minute 
to see it.  He has got the 
Indians cause at heart 
and does all he can in 
his way to help them but 
he can’t do much as he 
says he would be put 
off the reservation he is 
working awful hard for 
the Indian Agency here 
at the Crow Agency the 
Crows all want him Agent 
and he has a lot of 
influential men working for

him I am going to send a 
letter to you that he wrote 
that was the means of 
throwing out the Agent that 
was here some time ago 
which explains things, 
now I wish you would 
write to Mr. Lyman Gage 
at Washington and say 
a good word for Mr. 
H. S. Campbell and am sure 
it would do a lot of 
good.  I want to see him 
get in as he is a good 
square man and the 
Indians honest friend.  
I probably will be here 
for some time, as the 
Indians have promised me 
they would fix up for me 
just as they were at the 
War Dance.  I will send 
you some letters written

(9) to Mr. Campbell by 
full blood Crow Indians 
at School.  If things keep on 
as they have there is going 
to be trouble here sure as 
the World as the Indians 
say themselves they have a bad 
heart and who could blame 
them, they are almost starving 
and are not allowed to kill 
any of their cattle to eat, if 
they do they are locked up for 
30 days and have to work hard 
and nothing hurts an Indians 
pride more than that If the Indian 
could only get his just dues 
he would be perfectly happy 
and if Mr. Campbell gets to be 
Agent he will be honest with 
them You can address me 
at Crow Agency, 
Mont 
and my letters will

will be forwarded here.  
With love to all.
Am your affect 
nephew
Elbridge

St. Xavier Mont
July 22/97
My dear Uncle
I have finished my 
12th picture so far have 
a better lot of pictures 
that I got at Ft. Sill.  
That is they are more 
interesting and more 
artistic as the costumes 
are so fine the finest ever 
saw, painted two pictures 
of Chief Medicine Crow 
in dance costume and 
Chief costume.  I wrote 
you some few days 
ago to send Tot 
$50.00 and me $100.00 
haven’t heard from

you as yet Wish you 
would send Tot 
$50.00 right off her 
address is Mrs. E. A. Burbank, 
care of Mrs William Thorne, 
24 West 59th Street, New 
York.  And wish you would 
send me a check for 
$100.00 right off you can 
send the letter to me 
here and I can get it 
cashed here.  I haven’t 
taken in any money since 
last March and have 
drawn from the bank 
At the Indian exhibition 
Thurber sold two of the 
Indians the small 
ones for $300.00.  I 
had all the Indian

(3) pictures framed at Thurber 
and the commission on the 
two pictures sold and 
other frames I owed him 
for them wasn’t much 
left of the $300.00.  I 
do not know how long 
will remain here expect 
for some time yet it 
will take me a month 
to paint what Indians 
have engaged ahead 
expect to have at 
least 30 pictures when 
return to Chicago.  There 
are the finest subjects 
I ever saw among the 
Indians here they fix 
up so fine and have

so many fine costumes 
some of them have three 
different costumes.  
One of the portraits I 
painted of Chief Medicine 
Crow he had a tame 
live bird perched on top 
of his head it went 
with his costume.  The 
other one painted of him 
was a large one standing 
in War dance costume 
his face was painted 
a bright yellow mouth 
and all he was partly 
nude with a black horses 
tail fastened on behind 
and an Indian scalp in 
his hand on his legs 
and arms were red 
rings painted representing 
Sioux Shoshone & Nez 
Percy Indians he had 
killed in single fights

I was going to paint another 
of him profile but he 
got tired said he 
would sit later on 
An Indian gave me 
a large picture he painted 
of a stock ranch which 
is very good.  I received 
a nice letter from 
Mr. Holmes he gave me 
some good suggestions 
which will accept.  
Well I must close.
Your affect nephew,
Elbridge
St Xavier Mont.

Crow Agency 
Mont.
July 29/97
My Dear Uncle,
I wrote you nearly 
4 weeks ago asking you to send 
me $100.00 and Tot $50.00 I haven’t 
heard from you as yet and have 
written you twice I think since 
about the money and now I 
haven’t enough money to last me a 
week I am worried about 
Tot as she is in New York 
visiting friends, of course she has 
no board to pay, but of course 
can’t be without any money and 
it worries me and I want to 
put all my mind to my work.  
I left St. Xavier yesterday I 
painted 10 Indians while there

the best I have made yet.  I could 
of remained longer as there was 
plenty of good subjects for me 
but I couldn’t stand the 
living it is 25 miles from here 
by wagon and they can’t get 
fresh things to eat I never 
want to see any more bacon or 
ham had it three times a day 
for 3 weeks and canned things 
and couldn’t get washing done 
only by sending it 25 miles 
couldn’t get shaved or hair 
cut and when I arrived here I 
looked like a wild man.  I 
expect to be here a long time 
have got 12 Indians engaged to 
sit for me all of these Chiefs 
have a nice place to live in 
and a nice place to work.  
Tomorrow commence on a Chief 
called Bears Claw with war

(3) bonnet on, all the Indians am 
to paint are noted ones Hamlin 
Garland has been here and the 
Cheyenne Agency some three weeks 
he has gone West now to 
the Black feet.  I can’t possibly 
get along on less than $100.00 
a month.  The Indians cost me 
$60.00 a month.  I work 8 hours 
a day Sunday and all then 
the cheapest I can get board 
and room is $1.00 a day or $30.00 
a month which is $90.00.  Then 
there is my washing and then the 
Indians live all the way 
from one mile to 40 miles 
from here and I have to send 
an Indian Police to get them 
which costs me a $1.00 each 
time he goes.  Then I have to 
travel so much by stage 
which costs since left Chicago 
I have been to two Indian 
reservations and have traveled 
300 miles by wagon to get to

the Indians.  Then I have to travel 
on Railroads I have no pass 
on, have to pay my fair and that 
counts up.  This place is 61 miles 
from Billings on the Burlington Road.  
So you see I have to figure 
mighty close to make it on $100.00 
a month.  But it will pay me.  
I have been gone now 6 weeks 
and from the day I left Chicago 
to now have painted 13 pictures 
which I will sell eventually 
for $2,450.00.  The next 6 weeks I will 
paint at least 20 more pictures.  
I haven’t taken in any money at 
all since last March and that 
was $300.00 for Antiquarian picture.  $30.00 of it 
paid in commissions for selling 
pictures and the rest of it the Indians at 
Ft. Sill got.  Besides my living there, 
buying me some clothes, 
etc.  When I got to Chicago 
drew all the money I had in 
the Bank, $300.00 and with it

(5) it squared up all my debts in 
Chicago which was more than 
I thought and when I left 
Chicago had $200.00 clear, 
had to pay my fare to St. Paul, 
and had to pay at Ft. Yates 
$2.40 a day for board.  It was the 
only place there and had to, or else 
go away and some of the Indians 
had to pay $3.00 a day and 
now I have left enough to 
last a week.  I have to pay these 
Indians every day, my board 
won’t have to pay until end of 
month.  The Indians here I keep 
them with me all day, at 
Noon I have them eat with me 
and I pay for their dinner, in that 
way I loose no time.  At 
Ft. Sill I would have one Indian 
in forenoon and at Noon let 
him go home and after Dinner 
have another Indian.  Sometimes 
he wouldn’t come until 2 or 3 
o’clock and I would loose

time so by having them all day 
with me I loose no time.  
If I had some money in the bank 
I wouldn’t bother you at all 
I suppose I could borrow money 
here of the Indian trader and 
give him all my pictures for 
security but I don’t like to do 
it not knowing the man.  He might 
claim I sold them to him for 
$100.00 or the sum borrowed of him.  
I am here among strangers and 
every turn I take cost me something 
but I am here to paint Indians 
and I am going to paint them 
until late in the Fall, as I tell 
you now is the time to get 
them as in a very few years 
the Indian will loose his identity.  
They are doing all they can now 
on this (Crow) reservation to 
induce the Indians not to paint 
up and do away with his 
feathers, costumes, etc. I feel

(7) sure you have sent the money 
and maybe it is lost.  
The Art Amateur in New York 
City have me a nice notice 
about my Ft. Sill Indians 
it spoke of you also. I am 
having the worst luck with my 
wheel last Sunday I was 
riding on a fine road going 
at a 4 mile gait and 
the front rim snapped right 
in two, never heard of a rim 
doing it before unless run into 
something pretty hard.  This is 
the second time it has done it 
so I sent the front wheel to 
Chicago with instructions to get 
me the strongest rim that 
was made.  Below is a list of 
the Indians am to paint all of these 
Chiefs except White Swan he was 
Reno’s Scout in the Custer fight 
and was shot in 3 or 4 places 
his head was cut open with

a tomahawk and left for dead 
but he is a live Indian.  
Old dog, Spotted Horse, 
Deaf Bull (he is a specially noted 
Indian) Bull-goes-a-hunting, Bears Claw, 
Big Medicine, Takes-a-wrinkle, 
Crazy Head, Shoulder Blade, 
Medicine Tail, Bull Tongue & While Swan.  
Remington was here one a few months 
ago he comes here quite often.  
With love to you Aunt Emma 
& Lizzie.  Sincerely hope I 
will hear from you this week.
Am Your affect nephew
Elbridge

Crow Agancy Mont
July 31/97
My dear Uncle
Yours reced" with
check for $100.00 enclosed which am much
obliged for also the $75.00 you sent
Tot.  I wish you were here to see
these Crow Indians  they are the
finest Indians have seen yet,
Tomorrow will have a picture
finished of Chief Bears Claw
have him with a War bonnett on
his face all  painted up and has
on the most beautiful jacket ever
saw it is completely covered with
beads and  has Sioux Indians on
horse back in bead work on the
front and on the back is bead
work where the Crows have scalped

the Siouxs and are marching home
I will get to the Nez Percey Indians
to get Chief Joseph and Chief
Moses  he is there also but dont
think I will get any further
this time  Capt Watson who is
the Indian Agent here and a
batchelor has invited me to sleep
in his house  I  have a large front
room and a large bed room also
then in another house I have a fine
studio  so I am fixed fine.
Capt Watson chased old Geronimo
for three years and never got
with in a half mile of him
he could see Geronimo and Naiche
in the distance  he was telling me
about it this eve"  he said that
was the most brilliant army maneuvering
on Geronimo's part in the history of
the U.S.  he said several Company's 
were after him and could'nt catch

(3) him.  Tomorrow afternoon (Sunday)
another fellow who knows the
ground and myself are going over
the Custer battle field on horse back
and I will take some snap shots
today have been reading about
the battle.  am going to paint While
Swan  he was Reno's Scout and
was shot and given up for dead
saw him this eve"  The Indians
here have so many costumes that
I am going to remain here for 
some time,  every body is so kind
to me.  What name do you thing
the Crows have given me here
it is "Bach-who-ah-rad-she"
Mr Campbell at St. Xavier happened
to be among a lot of Indians when
Pretty Eagle was describing to them
about my pictures (he had just
been with me watching me.)  he says
that fellow Mr Campbell is different
from you white people  I did'nt
know white people could draw

before, every Indian can draw some
and most of them good but that
fellow makes a wiggle with his
brush and there is a feather  he
makes a few more wiggles and
there is an eye etc  and he
says it is an eye too  it looks
right at you and the mouth does all
but talk etc.  The picture I
have of Pretty Eagle the profile
is the best picture every have
painted  he is fixed up so fine
all the time I was painting him
he held a looking glass in his
hand and kept looking at him
self now and then.  I painted
a little papoose 3 years old
I thought the parents would steal
it one time,  had to hide it.
Pretty soon amy going to send
what pictures have finished
to Chicago  have 14 now
I have it fine here any time

(5) I want an Indian the Indian
police go and get him for me
which saves me lots of time
and riding around  Hamlin Garland
was awfully enthusiastic over
this place so they tell me,
he is coming back.  There are
some fine Indian Artists here
and if you want them to do
some work for you let me know
I have a large picture that
an Indian made me a present of
In a few years the Crows wont
have any costumes at all,  if
The Government knew how much
the Indians dance the costumes
would soon go as that is all
their costumes are for.  they
dance every Sunday and every
big day like 4th of July.  You
probably know of Deaf Bull
a Crow Chief  he is about
the most noted Crow  he was
sent to Ft Snelling some time
ago  he called on me yesterday

am going to paint him  There is
a Mr Barstow here who sold
you a lot of Indian things some
years ago through another
fellow  he said what he sold 
you was what he had gathered
him self personally and was
the finest collection of its kind
he had seen  he has been here
over 20 years.  Well I must
close  with love to all
Am Your affect
nephew
Elbridge.
Crow Agency   Mont.

Crow Agency
Aug 8/97 Mont
My dear Uncle
I will send today
by Adams Express a
package of Indian pictures
which wish you would
please have put in the
safe as it is dont want
the box opened as have
the pictures screwed together
so they will not touch
Pretty soon will send
some more  have finished
now 16 pictures,  Have had
some trouble lately to
get the Indians to sit as
they have been busy haying
but tomorrow Monday

Deaf Bull has promised
to come.  Expect to go
to the Cheyenne Indians
in a few days  have to
travel 65 miles by wagon
to get there, expect to
get some good subjects
there and from there
will go to the Nez Perces
Indian's
Received the telegram
from you.
The Indians are to
give a War dance Today
I may go and see it.
With love to all
Am your affect
nephew
Elbridge
